Posts.Title: Ohio Chemo Sisters Kelloggs Kelloggs

Posts.Content: May 4, 2013 08:16PM jojo69 wrote: Hi ladies!  I thought I'd give everyone an update since I started chemo.  I've had an interesting turn of events of late.  My oncologist called me at home on a Sunday afternoon a few weeks ago.  Nervous, cause that's never a good sign, I called her back.  Turns out that as she was going over my info she discovered a discrepency in my original pathology & the final pathology from my surgery.  The first pathology(which was done with IHC) deteremined that I was HER 2+, where the final pathology(which was done with FISH) showed me as HER 2-.  She called the hospital where I had my original diagnosis & asked to look at their results again.  The pathologist there said he was confident in his original diagnosis.  So right up until the morning I started chemo my oncologist was sure what to do.  If there was even a chance that I was HER 2+ she wanted to start my chemo with the herceptin.  She decided to just start without the herceptin & change my chemo to taxotere & cytoxin, rather than the original taxotere, carboplatin, herceptin.  She sent my cancer for oncotype & asked for the original pathology be sent for FISH testing.  She finally got everything back this last week & all but that original diagnosis was HER 2-!  She feels the first was just lab error & she feels confident that I am HER 2-.  She said this NEVER happens & it's a miracle.  My oncotype was only 14!  She said my re-occurence rate with just tamoxifen is 9% and with chemo & tamoxifen is only 6%!  She & I both feel that doing 4 rounds of TC (especially since I've already done 1 round) is worth the side effects to get that extra 3%.  So my original diagnosis/treatment was 17 treatments total between the chemo and hercpetin followed by tamoxifen is now only 4 TC treatments followed by tamoxifen!  And with a super low re-occurence rate!  I just cannot believe how much that little error has changed everything.  I am so thankful my oncologist caught it.   As far as the chemo, the first round wasn't bad at all.  I did have to go to the ER one night.  My WBC tanked & I spiked a fever.  They just sent me home with a round of antibiotics & my numbers were up again 2 days later.  I was really proactive about taking the zofran & had no nausea at all.  I had a few aches & pains with the Neulasta shot but nothing I couldn't handle with some tylenol.  I was really really tired most of the first week, but I'm at day 9 post chemo & I feel great.  I have more energy & was able to get a lot of stuff done yesterday & today.  Biggest complaint is that I can't really taste anything.  Everything smells so good, but tastes like nothing.  Not bad, just bland.  I'm a foodie, so this is a hard one for me:(.  Overall, I really can't complain at all.  Nothing has been nearly as bad as I had imagined.  Of course, I still have my hair.  I may change my tune in a few weeks:) Ok, sorry this is so long winded.  I just wanted to let you all know how I'm doing & share my good news:)  Hope you all are enjoying this beautiful sunshine.  I know I am:)
Posts.Title: Ohio Chemo Sisters Kelloggs Kelloggs

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 04:23PM jojo69 wrote: Debbie, I actually live in Orrville, near Wooster.  I really like my Wooster surgeon that diagnosed me, but I just feel like I need to go to a hospital where they do these surgeries more frequently.  I'm pretty sure I am going to go the route of bilateral mastectomy because I have cancer in one breast & ADH in the other.  I'm just so confused by everything right now.  I just want to get started & figure out  what I'm dealing with.  All I know right now is I have IDC & I'm ER+PR+HER2+.  I have no idea about grade, size, stage.  It's so hard not having complete information & then having to wait so long to find out.  And to top it all off, we have a long awaited Hawaiin vacation planned for January 26-Feb 3. So, even after getting my second opinion I have to decide to either wait til I get back to have surgery or cancel my trip to deal with everything!

Posts.Content: jojo69 wrote: Let me just start by saying I'm new to all this, BC, discussion boards,etc. so please forgive me this post is a little awkward.  I was just diagnosed this week with BC after being diagnosed with ADH about 6 months ago in my other breast.  My surgeon doesn't know much about the size, stage, etc. until she does surgery, but her feeling is it is small & hopefully stage 1.  After the shock of the diagnosis & crying nonstop for 2 days I decided I needed to seek help in making decisions on how to proceed.  My surgeon offered me the the option of lumpectomy & radiation or mastectomy.  I'm seriously leaning toward doing a bilateral mastectomy, even though it terrifies me, because of BC in one breast & ADH in the other.  I'm a worrier & I just want to do what I can to prevent future worries, cancers, etc.  I live in a small town & the surgery would be done at a community hospital.  I have made an appointment for a second opinion with a surgeon at a larger hospital nearby but I can't get in to see her for another 3 1/2 weeks.  Then I am leaving for Hawaii (not giving up this long awaited vacation) 1 week after that for 8 days.  It makes me nervous to wait that long, we're looking at close to 2 months since dx before anything gets done.  Does this seem like a long time to wait?  My current surgeon assures me that BC is a slow growing cancer & I should take my time to make an informed decision.  She suggested doing the lumpectomy next week & that I could always decide on the masectomy later.  Part of that appeals to me because I just want this cancer out of my body like YESTERDAY, but is it bad to do 2 surgeries when I'm pretty sure I want to do the masectomy in the end anyway?  Do I just wait until I get my second opinion before I do anything?  I can use any and all advice please! Dx 12/18/2012, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 2/22/2013 Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Chemotherapy 4/25/2013 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 9/27/2013 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 02:25PM jojo69 wrote: Yes, I have had a biopsy.  This all started back in March of this year.  I had biopsy on rt breast following suspcious microcalcifications shown on mammogram.  Surgeon did breast exam & felt small lump on left breast so she decided to do ultrasound the same day she did biopsy on rt breast.  Rt breast came back with ADH, but no cancer was found after excision of area.  After ultrasound on left breast they decided it was just dense breast tissue & I was told not to worry about it.  I went back for 6 month check back of rt breast (which was fine) & asked the surgeon(different surgeon, I was not happy with the first) to see what she though about the left breast cause I just was a little paranoid.  She felt it & really thought it was dense tissue as well, but suggested biopsy just so we both could feel better about it.  Well, we were both shocked when it came back cancer.  Now Im freaking a little because I'm wondering it has been cancer this whole time & they told me it was just dense tissue.  That's why I'm a little worried to wait for second opinion.  I was considering doing this lumpectomy at my community hospital just to have it out & then going to the bigger hospital for mx & reconstruction after hawaii.  I just dont know how any of this works.  Is it bad to have 2 surgeries, does insurance usually cover both?  I know Im er/pr+ her-, but when I asked her about stage & size all she said was I THINK it's small & HOPE it's stage 1 but wont know until surgery.  Is that weird that she can't tell?
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2012 01:54PM jojo69 wrote: Linda, thank you for that last post. It really moved me.  Like I said earlier, I am a worrier, and typically go to the worst case scenario, mostly so I'm never surprised or disappointed.  Not a great way to go through life, I know, and its something I've struggled with my whole life.  However, I am even surprising myself with my reaction & the way I'm dealing with this dx(after my initial 2 day pity party after the dx).  I may be a little "pie in the sky" with my thoughts on how this is going to go, but I really feel like I just want to get started with everything because my hope is I will get it taken care of & move on with my life.  I know there is a chance it may not go that way, but I'm feeling pretty positive at this point.  I really appreciated you sharing how you've grown to treasure each delay in the process.  I'm trying even harder to embrace that way of thinking. I had another thought today that hopefully someone can help me with.  Like I said, I am scheduled for a second opinion with a breast surgeon that was recommended from a friend of a friend.  It got me wondering if there are more area specific threads on this board.  It would be really nice to find other women that live near me & can recommend doctors, pathologists, etc.  Does anyone know if there is something like that on this site?
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2012 03:19PM jojo69 wrote: I'm sorry, I only included the comment from my pathology report.  The first this it says is microsopic diagnosis-left breast tissue, core biopsy: moderately differenciated invasive ductal carcinoma.  Focal ductal carcinoma in situ.  So yes, it is invasive.  I even asked the surgeon to make sure because it seems to only have comments on the dcis.  I'm assuming I have both present in the breast?  I did call the surgeon yesterday to cancel the lumpectomy that was  scheduled for today.  I feel like I was just rushing into that decision because I want to get something done as soon as possible.  I asked her again about the grade & she said there was no other information about the grade, maybe because the sample tissue wasn't large enough to get more information.  I still don't understand that.  I feel like I should know more than I do about what I'm dealing with.  Anyway, I've decided I am not doing anything until I go for my second opinion.  Unfortunately that means waiting another 3 weeks because that surgeon is out of the office all next week & that is the soonest I could get in!  If I've learned anything, it's don't get diagnosed with cancer around the hoidays.  I guess I'm being taught a lesson in patience.  Now if I can just calm my nerves for 3 more weeks.  It's so hard not to imagine the cancer growing/spreading inside while I wait!
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 01:11PM jojo69 wrote: Thank you for all the responses.  I have to say in this terrible time it is so nice to be able to talk stuff out with so many others who have been through this.  I have lots of love & support around me, and my family & friends have been wonderful, but they are more clueless than I am at this point.  I'm so thankful I found this website & discussion group. That said, I feel like I should know more of what I'm dealing with at this point.  I keep reading other posts where people seem to know the stage, grade, etc before they have any type of surgery.  I feel like I would feel so much better about waiting to make decisions if I knew what I was working with here.  My surgeon has not ordered an MRI.  Would I know more if I had had one?  Is that where they determine stage, grade, etc? Linda, I am 43 & the only family history I have is my dad's mother.  I do have ADH in my other breast which puts me at a higher risk for developing cancer.  My surgeon is pushing for the BRCA test but mentioned that some insurances don't cover it.  I'm still working all that out because I do want to have it done.  If I test positive I would have no doubts or regrets about having bilateral mastectomy. I'm also wondering about having lumpectomy then bilateral?  Does it make reconstruction harder?  Would I still do radiation before the other surgery?
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2012 08:40PM jojo69 wrote: Thank you for the advice.  I did start a new thread & hopefully someone from my area will see it & respond.  I know I should not limit my care to only what is near by.  I did go on the nccn site & the closest cancer center is about 3 hours away.  I have been hearing good things about the surgeon I'm seeing for my second opinion.  Also the PS I'm hoping to meet with is highly recommended & offers immediate DIEP or implant reconstruction.  I'm really hoping that I am happy once I meet with them & can stay closer to home for the surgery.
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 02:55PM jojo69 wrote: On the pathology report it says intermediate nuclear grade, focal central necrosis.   Is that what determines the grade?  I'm sorry, this is all greek to me.  I feel like I've already asked my surgeon a million questions & new ones keep popping up.  Of course its Saturday & I can't call the office.
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2012 03:44AM jojo69 wrote: Bryona, yes, this is not exactly what I want for Christmas:(  Trying really hard to put it out of my mind somewhat & enjoy the time with my family.  To answer your question, no I don't see anything about mitotic count or tubule formation.  All it says is Ductal carcinoma in situ shows cribriform pattern, intermediate nuclear grade, focal central necrosis and comprises about 10% of the total tumor volume.  Am I missing something?  My surgeon only did a core needle biopsy, not sterotactic.  She really felt it was just dense breast tissue so she didn't want to put me through the the sterotactic.  Could that be why I don't have all that information?
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2013 10:52AM jojo69 wrote: Hi ladies, guess I'm joining your group.  I will start start chemo on April 18.  I will be spending the time before then getting all my scans & getting my port put in.  I've been so anxious to get started on this.  I was diagnosed before Christmas, had surgery in late February & while I know I have been healing, it seems like I've been waiting forever to start treatment!  As ready as I am to get going, I'm also really nervous.  The unexpected/unknown has been the worst throughout this entire cancer process.  Well, maybe the known losing my hair is pretty bad too.  I never thought I was  a vain person, but I'm kinda freaking about the hair thing.  I have a wig that I don't know if I'll wear.  I feel rather strange wearing it. I really bought it for the benefit of my kids (9 &11).  They seem to feel more comfortable with the idea of me wearing a wig. I have a couple of hats too, but I guess I need to get a few more & maybe figure out the scarf thing.  I feel like being proactive about it may make it easier to accept?  Anyway, it's so nice to have support from so many others going through the same crap as I am:)
